data.comments: observed flying over headed to Snettisham for fieldwork; moderate N winds transporting snow
Observed first by Dustin Carrol, morning of DOT daisybell mission. Slide occurred pre-mission. Slab width, vertical and elevation in feet.

Slid at beginning of massive outflow event, possibly during storm. Observed from Douglas Breeze In. Crown disappeared within first two days of wind. Debris observed 2/26 at Gold Creek level. Slab Thickness in cm. Width, vertical and elevation in feet.

Timelapse video of \\"Downtown Juneau from Douglas Island at 475ft elevation\\" on thesnowcloud.com showed slide occured at 08:30 and powderblast hit Perseverance Trail. High hazard on Gold Creek paths.
data.slab_type: Wind Slab going SS to HS

data.comments: 4th shot of Daisybell mission
data.path_location: Main central path of the face

data.comments: 3rd shot of Daisybell mission
Rapid wind stripping of light new snow creating isolated ribs of touchy windslab
Last Daisybell result of mission. Profile dug adjacent to crown.
Swept rider off his feet. Touchy ridgeline windslab ski cut nearby.
Multiple step-down/secondary slabs
multiple crowns in area
Ridgline and midbowl releases long propagations
Multiple stepdowns and secondary slides
data.path_location: Main bowl off the peak ridge
north of south rib main bowl

data.comments: entire north face of bride
Propagation cracks between two slides indicate simultaneous release, therefore calling it one whole avalanche
Reported by Steve Sano who saw the powdercloud hit the flume from basin road
Reported by Matt Callahan who triggered it and sent an email to Pat Dryer with photos
Observed from Roberts trail the day after major wind event that knocked down mny trees on the trail
Glide slide all the way to the ground, triggered secondary slide to the ground lower down in the path. date of event uncertain
wind slab
wind slab
may have been deeper and filled in before observed
thinner slab at similar elevation in a different chute
Multiple small surface slabs triggered by Daisy Bell before battery died.
Multiple small surface loose slides triggered by DOT Daisy Bell.
Small slab entrained lots of snow on the way down and developed a significant debris pile at the runout.
Natural noted as filled in; could have been from the 9th or 10th. Debris down into Gully; not sure how far down it went.
Visible across the Channel; can't see runout. Included pockets above the rock band.
Two shots from DOT cleared out storm slab from the previous day
One shot from DOT cleared out storm slab from the previous day
Scoped from downtown, also could see a slab crown just below the peak above the cliffs. No debris visible.
Powdercloud hit the flume, observed by Johnny B and on thesnowcloud.com timelapse at 09:30
Largest result of the short weather window for DOT daisybell. Powdercloud hit the road. A few smaller pockets released as well. Unable to reach Cross Bay Creek before weather moved in.
Slide heard by linecrew working above Basin Rd. I observed a small new debris pile at foot of the cliffs.
couldn't see crown
Observed after daisybell mitigation produced minimal results. Glide release occurred while dropping daisybell back at Snettisham.
Potentially reloaded from avalanche observed previous Saturday
Mid right pocket of upper SZ. Observed driving on Egan. Appears last night due to filled in a bit. Debris did not pass bench.

Slide crossed gold creek and perseverance trail sometime between 4/18 @ 1500 and 4/19 @ 1700. Temps warmer on 4/18 and smaller natural activity noted on adjacent slope at 1500 so 1600 most likely time of occurence.
High uncertainty on date of occurence, large chunk of cornice visibly broken off, many large chunks down below
Likely slid and refilled by intense winds. Hard to tell how deep it went.

Glide avalanche- post cool down. Noted in net radiation at BCY that skies cleared briefly this afternoon. Rob told me of the slide on 2/14 (noted it occurred between 3-5pm) after it blocked the Erection Bay entrance.
Natural that came pretty close to the campground as well as poles #14860 and #14861
Glide avalanche lower right went into trees above the gully. Don't know when released.
Series of glide releases that came down sometime in the last 2 weeks. Debris flowed through tower base.
Glide release that came close to diverter. Only a relatively small portion of SZ.
Daisybell control work released shallow storm snow layers. Dusted tower.
Natural released mid face in multiple pockets. Resulted in deep multi fingered wet debris in runout.
Natural glide release pushed well into trees just above the Diverter. Not sure when this released. Daisybell could not move anything else.

multiple debris piles, almost all of the gills slid
